Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this award is to organize the logistics portion of the annual Principal Investigators (PI) meeting for the National Robotics Initiative (NRI), which was launched in 2011. The PI meeting brings together the community of researchers, companies, and program officers who are actively engaged in the NRI to provide cross-project coordination in terms of common intellectual challenges, methods for education and training, best practices in education, technology transfer and general outreach, and a centralized and lasting repository illustrating the research ideas explored and milestones achieved by the NRI projects.

The meeting of the Principal Investigators of the National Robotics Initiative will be two days in October 2018 in the vicinity of Washington DC. The format will include presentations by the attending PIs of projects in their final year, a poster session with all other projects, keynote speeches, and panel discussions. Invitations to the meeting will include all PIs with active NRI grants, program managers with robotics-related programs, and members of the press. This award will take care of the venue, travel, A/V, supplies, and many of the personnel involved in organizing the meeting.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The fifth NSF National Robotics Initiative (NRI) PI Meeting, held Sunday, October 28 – Tuesday, October 30, 2018 at the Hilton Crystal City Hotel in Arlington, Virginia, brought together 210 community stakeholders comprising academic researchers, industry representatives, Government program managers, and non-profits who are actively engaged in the National Robotics Program.

NRI PI meetings are designed to:

·       advance knowledge by exposing the rich progress of basic research in the accelerated development and use of collaborative robots

·       learn about the efficacy of new, emerging NRI research and applications

·       discuss technology gaps and barriers

·       allow PIs to showcase their research results

·       provide an environment to network

The program of the meeting included invited keynotes, PI research project talks, PI research project poster sessions, and panel discussions about NRI research-related projects funded by NSF and other Federal agencies.

Keynote presentations were delivered by Professor Steven M. Lavalle (University of Oulu, Finland) and Professor John J. Leonard (MIT). Professor Lavalle spoke about The Path to (Human) Perception Engineering on day 1. Professor Leonard presented on the topic of, The Challenges and Opportunities in Autonomy: Lessons From Self-Driving Cars on day 2.

The program was organized by a program committee comprising NRI community experts identified by NSF.  

The National Science Foundation established the NRI program to accelerate the development and use of robots in the United States that work beside or cooperatively with humans ubiquitously in every aspect of life. The focus is on the entire lifecycle from fundamental research and development to manufacturing and deployment. NRI research is supported by multiple agencies of the federal government including the National Science Foundation (NSF), the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA), the National Institutes of Health (NIH), the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA), the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE), and the U.S. Department of Defense (DOD).

Information and artifacts (e.g., talks, videos, poster content, etc.) about the 2018 NRI PI Meeting are permanently archived on the 2018 NRI PI Meeting website which is housed on the CPS VO platform, a web portal, which was built, operated, and managed by the Institute of Software Integrated Systems (ISIS) at Vanderbilt University with funding support from NSF.

 


Last Modified: 09/04/2020
Modified by: Frankie King
